item.label: Cerebral gyrus, Cingulate
item.name: Cingulate gyrus
item.description: The cingulate gyrus is the region of the cerebral cortex that arcs above the corpus callosum on the medial aspect of the hemisphere. Along with the parahippocampal gyrus to which it is connected by the isthmus of the cingulate gyrus, posterior to the splenium of the corpus callosum, it is considered to be the "Limbic lobe" of the brain.

item.label: Cerebral gyrus, Precentral
item.name: Precentral gyrus
item.description: The precental gyrus is a vertically-oriented gyrus of the cerebral hemisphere located immediately anterior to the central sulcus. Functionally, it serves as the primary motor cortex. The body and head are represented somatotopically within the gyrus such that the head is located laterally near the lateral sulcus and the feet are located most medially in the longitudinal fissure. In Brodmann's designation, this gyrus is termed Area 4.

item.label: Cerebral gyrus, Postcentral
item.name: Postcentral gyrus
item.description: The postcentral gyrus is the vertically-oriented gyrus of the cerebral hemisphere located immediately posterior to the central sulcus. Functionally, it serves as the primary somatic sensory cortex. The body and head are represented somatotopically within the gyrus such that the head is located laterally near the lateral sulcus and the feet are located most medially in the longitudinal fissure. In Brodmann's designation, this gyrus is termed Areas 3,1,2.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Central
item.name: Central sulcus
item.description: The central sulcus (of Rolando) is an important sulcus on the lateral aspect of the cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal from the parietal lobes. It extends from just medial to the superior border of the hemisphere downward to the lateral or Sylvian fissure. The primary motor and somatosensory areas of cortex form the gyri (pre-central and post-central, respectively) on either side of this sulcus.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Precentral
item.name: Precentral sulcus
item.description: The precentral sulcus forms the anterior boundary of the precentral gyrus and separates it from the remaining horizontally-arranged frontal gyri.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Postcentral
item.name: Postcentral sulcus
item.description: The postcentral sulcus forms the posterior boundary of the postcentral gyrus and separates this gyrus from the remainder of the parietal lobe.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Cingulate
item.name: Cingulate sulcus
item.description: The cingulate sulcus curves over and immediately dorsal to the cingulate gyrus on the medial aspect of the cerebral hemisphere. Posteriorly, a marginal branch extends toward the superior surface of parietal lobe, demarcating the posterior boundary of the paracentral lobule.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Marginal
item.name: Marginal sulcus
item.description: The marginal sulcus is the portion of the cingulate sulcus that separates the paracentral lobule from the precuneus.  It is AKA the marginal branch of the cingulate sulcus.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Calcarine
item.name: Calcarine sulcus
item.description: The calcarine fissure or sulcus is AKA as Area 17 of Brodmann. It is a prominent sulcus on the medial surface of the occipital lobe consisting of an upper bank (cuneus) and lower bank (lingual gyrus) where the neurons of the primary visual cortex are located.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Parieto-occipital
item.name: Parietooccipital sulcus
item.description: The parieto-occipital sulcus is a deep fissure that divides the parietal from the occipital lobes on the medial aspect of the cerebral hemisphere.

item.label: Olfactory bulb & tract
item.name: Olfactory tract
item.description: Located on the ventral surface of the orbital gyri of the frontal lobe, the olfactory tract consists of the axons of the olfactory bulb neurons. These axons branch into the medial and lateral olfactory stria forming the olfactory trigone; they will terminate in the olfactory (piriform) cerebral cortex as well as the amygdala.

item.label: Commissure, Corpus callosum
item.name: Corpus callosum
item.description: The corpus callosum is a massive curved commissure that interconnects corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres so that these areas may function in a coordinated manner.

item.label: Internal capsule
item.name: Internal capsule
item.description: The internal capsule is a thick fiber bundle that is the primary route of communication between the cerebral cortex and other CNS structures. It includes the thalamocortical, corticothalamic, corticospinal, corticobulbar, etc. tracts. It consists of an anterior limb, genu and posterior limb that form a "V" shape as seen in mid-level horizontal or axial sections.   The lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus) is located laterally inside the "V" and the caudate nucleus and thalamus are located medially.

item.label: Anterior limb
item.name: Ant limb
item.description: The anterior limb of the internal capsule is located between the lenticular nucleus laterally and the head of the caudate nucleus medially. It includes thalamocortical fibers from the dorsomedial and anterior thalamic nuclei to the prefrontal and cingulate areas of cerebral cortex as well as corticopontine fibers.

item.label: Genu
item.name: Genu
item.description: The genu of the internal capsule is located where the anterior and posterior limbs meet. It includes connections between the ventral anterior (VA) and ventral lateral (VL) thalamic nuclei with the motor/premotor cerebral cortex as well as corticopontine fibers.

item.label: Posterior limb
item.name: Post limb
item.description: The posterior limb of the internal capsule is located between the lentiform nucleus laterally and the thalamus medially. It includes connections between the ventral anterior (VA), ventral lateral (VL), ventral posterior nuclei (VPL/VPM) of thalamus with the motor, somatosensory and other areas of parietal cerebral cortex as well as corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers. A portion of the posterior limb passes beneath the lentiform nucleus (sublenticular); it includes the auditory radiation from the medial geniculate nucleus of thalamus to the temporal lobe of the cerebral cortex and a portion of the optic radiation from the lateral geniculate nucleus to the occipital cerebral cortex. A portion of the posterior limb passes posterior to the lentiform nucleus (retrolenticular); it includes a major portion of the optic radiation from the lateral geniculate nucleus to occipital cerebral cortex plus connections between the thalamus (pulvinar and lateral posterior nuclei) and the parietal-occipital-temporal association cortex.

item.label: Caudate nucleus, Head
item.name: Caudate nucleus (head)
item.description: The head of the caudate nucleus is the largest portion of the caudate.  It bulges into the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle. It is located medial to the anterior limb of the internal capsule.

item.label: Thalamus
item.name: Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic nerve/chiasm
item.name: Optic nerve
item.description: The Optic nerve or Cranial Nerve II consists of the axons of ganglion cells in the retina. The optic nerve axons will travel through the optic tract and then synapse in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus as well as in the pretectum.  Between the optic nerve and lateral geniculate nucleus, the nerve fibers from the nasal half of the retina cross the midline in the optic chiasm and then enter the optic tract; the nerve fibers from the temporal half of the retina do not cross, but enter the optic tract directly.

item.label: Subthalamus
item.name: Subthalamus
item.description: The subthalamus is one of the four divisions of the diencephalon.  It is located ventral to the thalamus, lateral to the hypothalamus and medial to the internal capsule and cerebral peduncle.  It contains the subthalamic nucleus and the zona incerta.  It is traversed by the somatosensory pathways on their way to the thalamus as well as by pathways connecting the cerebellum and basal ganglia.  It is continuous caudally with rostral portions of the red nucleus and substantia nigra.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Substantia nigra
item.name: Substantia nigra
item.description: The substantia nigra is a large band-like nucleus in the midbrain located between the crus cerebri and the red nuclei of the tegmentum. It has two parts: 1) a compact portion consisting of closely packed dopaminergic neurons filled with neuromelanin pigment. These neurons project to the striatum & are the ones damaged in Parkinson disease; 2) a reticular portion consisting of loosely packed neurons that receive input from the striatum and project to the thalamus.

item.label: Cerebral crus
item.name: Cerebral crus
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Trochlear nerve
item.name: Trochlear nerve
item.description: The fourth or trochlear cranial nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye. It is the only cranial nerve to exit the dorsal aspect of the brainstem. This location is just caudal to the inferior colliculi of the midbrain.

item.label: Pons
item.name: Pons
item.description: The pons is that portion of the brainstem between the midbrain and medulla. It consists of a basilar or basal portion that contains structures primarily associated with motor control and a tegmental portion that contains cranial nerve nuclei and important sensory tracts. The cerebellum overlies the pons and medulla. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on the dorsal surface of the pons. The pons and cerebellum originate embryologically from the metencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Abducens nerve
item.name: Abducens nerve
item.description: The abducens nerve is the sixth cranial nerve.  It innervates the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle. It exits the brain stem anteriorly at the pontomedullary junction.

item.label: Medulla
item.name: Medulla
item.description: The medulla is AKA the medulla oblongata. The most caudal aspect of the brain stem, it is located between the pons and spinal cord. It contains structures vital to survival such as cardiovascular and respiratory centers, as well as many cranial nerve nuclei. The major ascending and descending tracts travel through it between the spinal cord and higher centers. It originates developmentally from the myelencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Glossopharyngeal nerve
item.name: Glossopharyngeal nerve
item.description: The ninth or glossopharyngeal cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem along the lateral aspect of the medulla dorsal to the olive. The sensory component includes tactile sensation and taste from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue as well as input from the carotid body/sinus, middle and external ear; the motor component innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle (3rd pharyngeal arch origin) and provides the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that control secretion of the parotid gland.

item.label: Vagus nerve
item.name: Vagus nerve
item.description: The tenth or vagus cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem as a series of rootlets along the lateral aspect of the medulla dorsal to the olive and just caudal to the glossopharyngeal nerve. The most significant sensory component includes general sensation from the viscera, including input from the aortic body/sinus; the motor component innervates the laryngeal and pharyngeal muscles (4th and 6th pharyngeal arch origin) and provides the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that innervate the thoracic and abdominal viscera.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerebellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Deep cerebellar nuclei
item.name: Deep cerebellar nuclei
item.description: The deep nuclei of the cerebellum (dentate, globus, emboliform and fastigial nuclei) are located within the white matter core of the cerebellum. While they receive afferent input from extra-cerebellar sources, their main input is from the Purkinje cells of the cerebellar cortex. Their output constitutes the primary output of the cerebellum, per se, and travels primarily in the superior cerebellar peduncle to terminate in the motor part of thalamus plus in the red nuclei.

item.label: Middle cerebellar peduncle
item.name: Mid cerebellar peduncle
item.description: The middle cerebellar peduncle consists exclusively of pontocerebellar tract fibers that take their origin from pontine nuclei in the contralateral basilar pons. Thus, it carries afferent information to cerebellum from the contralateral cerebral cortex via the corticopontine to pontine nuclei to pontocerebellar tract.

item.label: Inferior cerebellar peduncle
item.name: Inf cerebellar peduncle
item.description: The inferior cerebellar peduncle is AKA the restiform body. Located on the lateral aspect of the medulla, it includes multiple tracts afferent to the cerebellum including the uncrossed dorsal or posterior spinocerebellar, cuneocerebellar, vestibulocerebellar, reticulocerebellar and crossed olivocerebellar. It also includes some cerebellar output tracts such as those projecting to the reticular formation and the vestibular nuclei.

item.label: Lateral ventricle
item.name: Lateral ventricle
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Choroid plexus
item.name: Choroid plexus
item.description: The choroid plexus is the convoluted and highly vascularized structure in the ventricles that is responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid.  It is located in the floor of the lateral ventricle as it curves from the body of the ventricle into the inferior horn; it is not present in the anterior or posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.  From the lateral ventricle, the choroid plexus extends through the interventricular foramina of Monro onto the roof of the third ventricle.  In the fourth ventricle the choroid plexus extends downward from the inferior medullary velum that forms part of the roof the ventricle.  The choroid plexus also extends from the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka into the subarachnoid space.
